skills.name: Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line
Order negative integers with the same number of digits
Use inequality notation to order negative integers with a different number of digits
Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers
Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers

explanations.A: I think you have counted up in 1s from -10. Make sure to count all the way to the next given number in order to check your intervals.
explanations.B: I think you have counted down in 1s from 2. Make sure to count all the way to the next given number in order to check your intervals.
explanations.C: The number line goes up in 2s, so we can countdown from 2 or up from -10. This gives us -4.
explanations.D: You may have counted in the wrong direction from 2. Make sure to count all the way to the next given number in order to check you are correct.

explanations.A: The scale goes up in intervals of 2. This gives us 0.
explanations.B: I think you have counted down in 1s from 4. Make sure to count all the way to the next given number in order to check your intervals.
explanations.C: I think you might have worked out the difference between 4 and -8. Now divide this by the number of sections between the numbers.
explanations.D: I think you have counted up in 1s from -8. Make sure to count all the way to the next given number in order to check your intervals are correct.

explanations.A: You may have forgotten to look at the negative signs. Try again, but make sure all your positive values come first.
explanations.B: You have correctly identified that the positive number comes first, but have made a mistake ordering your negative numbers. Try drawing them out on a number line.
explanations.C: You have instead placed your answers in ascending order. Descending means in order from greatest to smallest.
explanations.D: This is the correct descending order. We start with the greatest number and work our way down to the smallest. It may help to picture these on a number line.

explanations.A: You may have forgotten to look at the negative signs. Try again, but make sure all your positive values come first.
explanations.B: You have correctly identified that the negative numbers comes first, but have made a mistake when ordering them. Try drawing them out on a number line.
explanations.C: You have instead placed your answers in descending order. Ascending means in order from smallest to greatest.
explanations.D: The numbers are -5, -4, -2, 3 in ascending order. Ascending means in order from smallest to greatest. It can be helpful to draw them out on a number line.

explanations.A: You have correctly identified one of the marks as -4, but you have then counted on in the wrong direction. The arrow is pointing between -4 and -3. What number could this be?
explanations.B: A is halfway between -4 and -3, which is -3.5. Try drawing this out and filling in the missing numbers.
explanations.C: You may have counted in the wrong direction from -6. Make sure you count all the way up to the other given value to check you are correct.
explanations.D: It looks like you've counted in 2s. Make sure that if you're starting from -6 you count all the way up to 3 to check that your intervals are correct.

explanations.A: You have correctly identified one of the marks as 0, but you have then counted on in the wrong direction. The arrow is pointing between 0 and -1. What number could this be?
explanations.B: You may have counted in the wrong direction from -4. Make sure you count all the way up to the other given value to check you are correct.
explanations.C: The number line goes up in 1s, and A is halfway between 0 and -1. This makes it -0.5.
explanations.D: It looks like you've counted in 2s. Make sure that if you're starting from -4 you count all the way up to 5 to check that your intervals are correct.

explanations.A: You may have mixed up the inequality symbols. The opening of the inequality symbol is by the greatest number so you are looking for a number greater than -35. It may help you to draw a number line if you are still struggling.
explanations.B: This inequality symbol means that x is greater than -35. So we are looking for any number above -35 on a number line. -1 is greater than -35.
explanations.C: You may have mixed up the inequality symbols. The opening of the inequality symbol is by the greatest number so you are looking for a number greater than -35. It may help you to draw a number line if you are still struggling.
explanations.D: This inequality symbol means that x is greater than -35. x cannot be exactly -35.

explanations.A: This inequality symbol means that x is greater than -38. So we are looking for any number above -38 on a number line. 0 is greater than -38.
explanations.B: You may have mixed up the inequality symbols. The opening of the inequality symbol is by the greatest number so you are looking for a number greater than -38. It may help you to draw a number line if you are still struggling.
explanations.C: You may have mixed up the inequality symbols. The opening of the inequality symbol is by the greatest number so you are looking for a number greater than -38. It may help you to draw a number line if you are still struggling.
explanations.D: This inequality symbol means that x is greater than -38. x cannot be exactly -38.

explanations.A: You may have misread the scale. -3 will be exactly halfway between the -2 and -4 mark.
explanations.B: You may have misread the scale. -3 will be exactly halfway between the -2 and -4 marks. What number could be halfway between -3 and -4?
explanations.C: You may have counted in the wrong direction from -4. Look at the 2 dashes either side of the question mark. We have -4 and -3. What number could be between these?
explanations.D: Not all of the numbers are shown on this number line. Between −2 and −4 is −3. The arrow is between −3 and −4, so −3.5 is the only possible answer.

explanations.A: You may have counted in the wrong direction from -1. Look at the 2 dashes either side of the question mark. We have -1 and 0. What number could be between these?
explanations.B: Not all of the numbers are shown on this number line. Between 0 and −2 is −1. The arrow is exactly half way between 0 and −1, so −0.5 is the correct answer.
explanations.C: You may have misread the scale. -1 will be exactly between the -2 and 0 mark.
explanations.D: You're close! -0.25 is between the values of -1 and 0, but it looks like our arrow is pointing half way between these marks. What number is exactly half way between -1 and 0?
